discussion.content:
Range is - 20 to 19
-20 is highest priority
19 is lowest priority
So answer is C, need a lower priority

Selected Answer: C
Change to a lower priority
C is the correct answer

I agree with option C ( renice -n 10 -p 2864 )
I don't think D is the right option bcos the cmd renice -n -10 -p 2864 is wrong.
I agree that D is correct here. If priority -5 cannot solve the issue, then go lower to -10.

comments.content: A higher value of priority actually makes the process lower priority; it means the process demands fewer system resources (and therefore is a "nicer" process). A lower priority value means the process demands more resources, possibly denying those resources to processes that are "nicer".

discussion.content: D is correct

questions.question_text:
A systems administrator suspects a process with a PID of 2864 is consuming resources at an alarming rate. The administrator uses the command renice -n -
5 -p2864, but it does not solve the issue. Which of the following commands should the administrator execute to correct the issue?

discussion.content: Namespaces provide the isolation that containers offer, and cgroups provides the resource management.

https://jvns.ca/blog/2016/10/10/what-even-is-a-container/#:~:text=Basically%20there%20are%20a%20few,isolate%20processes%20from%20each%20other.&text=Basically%20these%20features%20let%20you,in%20the%20same%20Linux%20kernel.
best describes containers...

questions.question_text: Which of the following BEST describes containers running on a Linux system?

choices.A: Containers only need the namespaces functionality to run on a Linux system available since kernel 2.6.
choices.B: Containers need a hypervisor to run on a Linux system. Cgroups namespaces are functionalities used for the kernel but not for running containers.
choices.D: Containers use the cgroups and namespaces functionalities to isolate processes and assign hardware resources to each of those isolated processes.
choices.C: Containers only need the cgroups functionality for running on a Linux system. Namespaces is not a Linux kernel functionality needed for creating and managing containers.

questions.question_text: A systems administrator wants to download a package from a remote server. Which of the following are the BEST commands to use for this task? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
AB are the right answers.
- curl with the -o switch does download!

Selected Answer: AB
Curl and wget, just like you'd get something from a remote webserver.
NC is wrong because in order to use NC you need to setup the server first listening and then the client can transfer files once that is setup. CURL and WGET are correct.

so it's interesting, the question ask for "the BEST command", however, if you read the provided link in regards to ncat, it says the following, 
"NC can also be used to copy the files from one system to another, though it is not recommended & mostly all systems have ssh/scp installed by default"

If its NOT recommended, then its probably NOT considered "the BEST"

comments.content: So the right answer should be AB

discussion.content: NC is a C/S network tool. you need to run NC on the server-side so that you can download files by running NC on the client-side

BF looks good to me.
ncat or nc is networking utility with functionality similar to cat command but for network. It is a general purpose CLI tool for reading, writing, redirecting data across a network. It is designed to be a reliable back-end tool that can be used with scripts or other programs. It‚Äôs also a great tool for network debugging, as it can create any kind of connect one can need.
ncat/nc can be a port scanning tool, or a security tool, or monitoring tool and is also a simple TCP proxy. Since it has so many features, it is known as a network swiss army knife. It‚Äôs one of those tools that every System Admin should know & master.
https://www.linuxtechi.com/nc-ncat-command-examples-linux-systems/

comments.content: I agree. NC is a network tool. wget and curl seems to be the right answer

discussion.content:
Shouldn't it be AB?
Curl is also used to download data remotely from servers.

questions.question_text: An administrator is logged into a server remotely and wants to determine if the system is a VM. Which of the following commands would assist with this?

discussion.content:
It is A
sudo dmesg | grep -i hypervisor
[ 0.000000] Hypervisor detected: VMware

comments.content: yeah, it's dmesg. Vmstat is not even in the link they gave as a reference. Dmesg is.

discussion.content:
We can find the system's type using dmesg utility. dmesg is used to examine or control the kernel ring buffer.

To check if your Linux system is physical or virtual, simply run:

$ sudo dmesg | grep "Hypervisor detected"

If your system is physical, you will not see any output.

If your system is virtual machine, then you will see an output something like below.

[ 0.000000] Hypervisor detected: KVM

Selected Answer: A
Dmesg for sure, even the provided link agrees.
The link even shows that dmesg is a method.

vmstat = Virtual Memory Statistics, not 'Virtual Machine' status, as one might expect. You can use the command @igm displayed, or: sudo dmesg | grep "DMI" ... effectively producing the same results from the DMESG log (Ring Buffer) ...
There is even no "vmstat" in the link provided as answer!! üòÇ
It's A - that URL points to document that does not even mention vmstat - and vmstat memory, swap, pageins....
vmstat is used to view memory statistics

questions.question_text:
Ann, a Linux administrator, wants to edit a configuration management file. When she opens the file to edit, her text editor reports that the file has been opened in read-only mode. She then tries to edit the file as root by elevating via sudo and is still unable to save any changes. The error message in her text editor says that the read-only option is set on the file. Ann checks the permissions on the file and sees the following:
-rw-rw-r-- 1 root wheel 30 Jun 13 15:38 infrastructure.yml
Which of the following commands is the BEST option to allow her to successfully modify the file?

comments.content: omg you're right! I missed it

discussion.content: shouldn't be C? chattr -i

Selected Answer: C
She's running it as the user, root, when she's using sudo... which has write privileges. The only other explanation is that the file is immutable, and that attribute needs to be removed.

lsattr to check if the file is immutable 
if so we can use chattr -i to remove the immutable.

The reason why C is correct is because the user also tried editing the file as root and was unable to, even though, root is the owner of the file. Therefore, the file must be immutable and it needs to be removed with chattr -i command

Within the context of the question and the information given, answer D would be correct.

If the "i" attribute is set to the file, then that would also make it read only. However, since the only information given in the question is the standard permissions of the file, adding the "write" permission to other users would allow the user to edit the file.

comments.content: Using "-i" removes the immutable attribute and a "+i" would add it. D would not help since the file was not able to be written to using sudo when the owner is root and the group owner is wheel.

discussion.content: answer is c
the right answer should be C

comments.content: So the correct answer here is C.
Yes, i = immutable, but if you read further on the link you provided and on the commands man page, the - operator removes the attribute while the + operator adds it.

discussion.content:
I thought the file needed to be changed?
immutable ‚Äì the ‚Äúi‚Äù attribute makes a file immutable, which means that the file can‚Äôt be modifed, renamed, or deleted and no link to it can be created.
https://geek-university.com/linux/change-file-attributes/
